citation.article-title: A bacterial disease of guava, Psidium guajava caused by Erwinia psidii sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Erwinia psidii sp. nov.
Erwinia psidii sp.nov. (psi. di. i. L. n. Psidium generic name).
Straight rods. measuring 1.0-2.7x0.5-0.8 micrometers non spore forming, occurina singly, in pairs or short chains.
Gram negative and motile by pentrichous flagella.
Slow growth on GYCA and glucose nutrient agar media.
Colonies on KB medium are circular, smooth or wrinkled, glistening, white, without production of diffusible pigments on KB or on GYCA media.
Facultative anaerobe fermentative metabolism of glucose.
No growth factors are required and there is no visible development at 36°C after 7 days.
Acid ut no gas produced from the following carbohydrates; inositol, L-arabinose, orbitol, rhamnose, salicin dulcitol, mannose, sucrose, fructose, galactose and mannitol.
No acid produced from: rafffinose, cellobiose. lactose, xylose, trehalose, and α-methyl-glucoside.
Succinate is utilized, but not acetate, benzoate, malonate, oxalate and tartrate.
Positive in catalase, hydrogen sulphide, leaven, and reducing substances from sucrose.
Negative in oxidase, urease, acetoin, indol, nitrate reduction, casein and starch hydrolyses, pectate degradation and gelatin liquefaction.
Pathogenic to guava (Psidium guajara L.) causing a die-back of twigs and branches, characterized by a collapse of the vascular tissue.

In artificial inoculations, the bacterium was also pathogenic to strawberry guava (Psidium cattleianum Lam.), jambolana (Eugenia jambolana Lam.) and "melaleuca" (Melaleuca viridiflora Brogn. & Gris.).
The mol% G+C of the DNA is 51.7- 52.2 (Tm).
No hypmensitive reaction was observed on infiltrated tobacco leaves.
Isolates of Erwinia psidii sp. nov. have been deposited at the PDDCC, Aukland, New Zealand.
The isolate IBSBF 435 (=PDDCC 8426) is designated as the type culture of the bacterium.
